awd_abstract_narration:
This project is devoted to studies of zonotopal algebra and its combinatorial applications. The methodology  of zonotopal algebra is already known to play a role in  Approximation Theory (box splines), Commutative Algebra (fat point ideals, Cox rings), Enumerative Combinatorics (matroids and simplicial complexes), Convex Geometry (zonotopes and hyperplane arrangements), Graph Theory (Tutte polynomials, parking functions),  and Algebraic Geometry (hyperkaehler toric varieties, de Concini-Procesi wonderful models). This project seeks to advance the theory of zonotopal algebra in the following three ways: (1) develop a discrete counterpart to the existing continuous theory,  (2) apply zonotopal algebra to problems of algebraic and enumerative combinatorics, (3)  build the infrastructure for larger-scale collaboration on the subject.

This research effort should advance an important area at the crossroads of pure and applied mathematics. Results of this research may also have applications to the mathematics of large networks and traffic flow, including wireless communication, problems of statistical mechanics, scheduling, logistics and discrete optimization.  The project will involve graduate students and postdoctoral  scholars in and outside UC Berkeley. Junior participants will be encouraged to interact with each another within a research seminar at UC Berkeley as well as with more senior experts in the field during mutual collaboration visits.  This should contribute to the integration of research training and education.

por.por_cntn:
Zonotopal algebra studies specially structured finite-dimensional spaces of multivariate splines, polynomials, and/or exponentials. By virtue of their construction, these spaces encode a host of further information about other, related, objects. Such objects include matroids, simplicial complexes, parking functions, graphs and their many `counting functions' such as the Tutte polynomial, as well as zonotopes, i.e., Minkowski sums of finitely many line segments, and lattice points within them. In fact, zonotopal spaces can be built from zonotopes, justifying the somewhat unusual name of this research area.

Early research on what we now call `zonotopal algebra' can be traced back to efforts in analysis and approximation theory in 1980-1990s to understand (dimensions of) box spline spaces as solution sets of differential equations. Foundational work on zonotopal spaces in 2000-2010s by the participants of this project, and others, organically brought in algebraic and combinatorial techniques, achieving a simpler yet more general view of the area.

This project greatly improved our understanding of zonotopal spaces, various kinds of information they encode, and applications of zonotopal algebra primarily to problems of combinatorics. A `canonical' method to translate questions about graphs to questions about zonotopal spaces emerged as central to this work.

This method consists in using the incidence matrix of a graph to build a zonotope from its column vectors, leading to the zonotopal space whose properties `automatically' encode essential (i.e., matroidal) properties of the original graph.  This basic pathway: graph -> incidence matrix -> zonotope -> zonotopal space has been successfully employed to solve a number of open problems on graphs. For example, S. Brodsky used zonotopal spaces constructed in that fashion from so-called broken wheel graphs to capture the volumes of Stanley-Pitman polytopes and the polytopes appearing in their various subdivisions.

Further deepening of our understanding of zonotopal spaces came through their generalizations. One particularly powerful generalization by M. Lenz allows to construct zonotopal spaces directly from so-called forward exchange matroids. A forward exchange matroid is an ordered matroid together with a subset of its set of bases that satisfies a weak version of the basis exchange axiom.

The work on this project also led to a practical improvement of our understanding of zonotopal algebra via a symbolic algebra package created by B. Gillespie. This Sage package (available at https://github.com/bgillesp/sage-zonotopal-algebra) lets the user generate and display `classical' zonotopal spaces.

The work on the project led to two PhD theses, one software package, four journal publications, and several further papers in preparation. Results of this work were presented at multiple seminars, conferences and workshops. Judging from recent citations, this work has found a receptive audience willing and able to use zonotopal algebra in their own research.
